entry.title: Introducing the WalkMe-based alternative in-app help user experience: What and How to Activate
entry.content:
Good news! With the 2508 upgrade, SAP has released 12 standard, non-customizable WalkMe flows, ideal for accountants and sales representatives (no extra license; activation needed). 

SAP recently acquired WalkMe, which is a digital adoption platform that overlays your application to guide users how to navigate workflows step-by-step. Think of it as a tutorial with little bubbles that pop up and tell users where to click and what to input in fields when they're trying to complete a process, like create a sales order. 

Turn this on once and your users get step‑by‑step help in 33 languages* for high‑impact sales and finance tasks: Sales (Find/Edit/Create Order, Set Delivery Block, Add Shipping Instructions), Finance (Find/Change/Reverse/Copy Journal Entry, Customize Line Item View, View Related Documents), plus a homepage tour. These Smart Walk-Thrus are especially helpful to new users who need in-app guidance. Subject to change.

Persona

Embedded Flows

Apps in Scope

 General Accountant

  • Find a Journal Entry
  • Customize Line Item View
  • Change Line Item in a Journal Entry
  • Reverse Journal Entry
  • Copy a Journal Entry
  • View related documents in a Journal Entry

Manage Journal Entries - New Version (F0717A)

 Sales Rep

  • Create a Sales Order
  • Find a Sales Order
  • Edit a Sales Order
  • Set a Delivery Block
  • Add Shipping Instructions

Manage Sales Order - Version 2 (F3893)

 All Personas

  • Welcome to My Home

MyHome

 
*For more information like the available languages, please see SAP Note 3609634.

Note: If you are using SAP Enable Now, the WalkMe-based alternative in-app help user experience or WalkMe Premium is not available.

Activate (2–3 minutes): 

  1. Replace "Shell-home" with "#Shell-startGUI?sap-ui2-tcode=FTG_EXTERNAL" in the URL address to reach the configuration page within your customizing tenant (development/quality). This is a quick shortcut to reach the configuration activity page.
    1. Alternatively, navigate step-by-step to the configuration activity page:
      1. 2SL Customers with SB: Navigate to app "Manage Your Solution" -> Configure Your Solution -> Filter for "Application Area" - Application Platform and Infrastructure"; "Sub Application Area" - "General Settings" -> Basic Settings -> Configuration Steps -> Activate Features -> Configure
      2. 2SL & 3SL Customers with CBC: Navigate to app "Implementation Activities" -> General Settings-> Cross Application -> Activate New Features->Activate Features -> IMG Activity (clock with check symbol)

  2. Select feature: APS_UI_WME_INTEGRATION. Click 'Activate/Deactivate Feature' button near the top.
  3. Create/select transport if prompted. Name Transport to your liking. Close.
  4. Confirm State turns from red to green. Try the flows in dev before exporting to test and prod.

What happens next:

  • Open apps like Manage Journal Entries - New Version or Manage Sales Orders - Version 2 and click the question mark icon at the top of your page to open the WalkMe menu. Click on the Smart Walk Thrus under the Tours tab and you’ll see the bubbles guiding each step.
  • Notify the relevant users (ie. accountants and sales reps) how to find this and use this.

If you're interested in more WalkMe capabilities, like custom flows, analytics, and cross-app functionality (SAP and non-SAP apps), contact your SAP Customer Success Manager to find out more.

Have questions? Let’s chat in the comments!

entry.title: Get & Stay Secure in the S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition with the SAP EarlyWatch Alert Security Chapter
entry.content:
When moving to the public cloud with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, SAP is taking care of many security relates topics as cloud provider. However, in order to stay secure, customers are still responsible for the mitigation of risks such as business or technical users having critical authorizations.

Here, the SAP EarlyWatch Alert report in SAP for Me comes into play as it gives you insights into security risks in the chapter "Security (Public Cloud)". This chapter gives you insights and alerts you on the following topics:

  • Identity and Access Management - get additional information and resources on how to use Identity and Access Management (IAM) to establish, tailor, and monitor business roles to business needs and requirements
  • Deprecated Business Catalogs - revise deprecated business catalogs still in use that might be removed in future releases
  • Business Users Assigned to Many Business Roles - get alerted when business users have many business roles assigned, deviating from the best practice of only one per business user
  • Assignment of users to Business Role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR - check for usage of this role resulting in segregation of duties (SoD) conflicts as it is intended only for the initial configuration of a system
  • Use of Read/Write Unrestricted - be alerted on business roles having unrestricted write, read and value help access
  • Business Catalog Assignments - be warned about critical assignments of business catalogs to your business users
  • Communication (Inbound/Outbound) - find customer managed communication arrangements without certificate-based authentication using only basic authentication
  • Upcoming Certificate Expiration - early warning for certificates managed by the customer that will expire within the next 90 days

You can find more details on each of these chapters below or by directly accessing the SAP EarlyWatch Alert report* for your systems in SAP for Me. 

* an authorized users is needed to access this applicaion, refer to this SAP Support page on how to get access.

 

Identity and Access Management

Identity and Access Management (IAM) ensures that all business users within an organization have defined and managed business roles. With IAM, organizations can establish, tailor, and monitor business roles to business needs and requirements. There are several relevant applications available for managing IAM in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

The SAP EarlyWatch Alert provides an overview of relevant information and resources to enable the effective use of IAM.

 

Deprecated Business Catalogs

It is important to adapt existing Business Catalogs and Business Roles resulting from the addition of new scope items or a release upgrade. In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Business Catalogs are periodically revised. Some Business Catalogs will be deprecated and replaced by new ones. The deprecated Business Catalogs in the system may be removed by SAP at the time of a release after it has been declared as deprecated, so it is important to review the deprecated Business Catalogs after each release along with new scope items and make the necessary changes as soon as possible.

In this chapter, a list of deprecated business catalogs in use in the system and information how to handle this is provided.

 

Business Users Assigned to Many Business Roles

SAP best practice is to assign only one business role to a business user. Each business role must represent a workplace and business roles should be created from scratch using the workplace approach.  For production, it is strongly recommended to build production roles manually to ensure compliance with external and internal compliance rules for access.

In the this chapter, the system is checked for users that have multiple business roles assigned.

 

Assignment of users to Business Role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR

The role SAP_BR_ADMINISTRATOR is predefined by SAP and is intended only for the initial configuration of a system. Usage of this role in production does not correspond to SAP recommendations and may lead to compliance issues.

The system is checked for the usage of this role in this chapter to alert on the potential risk that comes along with using it.

 

Use of Read/Write Unrestricted

Using unrestricted fields in the maintenance of business roles allow users to have global data access, SAP best practices recommend to carefully review which users need to have restricted data access and maintain the access appropriately, e.g. ensuring employees only have access to data belonging to their sales organization.

This chapter informs about the number of busines roles with unrestricted write, read or value help access.

Use of Read/Write Unrestricted Result Table Example

 

Business Catalog Assignments

Business catalogs contain a bundle of privileges needed for accessing an app or features that are then assigned to users via business roles. This section checks for selected critical business catalogs and their assignment to business roles and users and rates this according to the valuationrules from SAP Note 863362. In case any critical business catalogs are assigned, additional details are presented as sub-chapters.

Business Catalog Assignments Overview Table Example

 

Communication (Inbound/Outbound)

It is recommended that certificate-based communication is used for technical users involved in inbound/outbound communication when possible. Usually, it is easier to detect if a certificate is compromised than detect if a password has been compromised. This chapter identifies whether any customer managed communication arrangements do not use certificate-based authenticate and provides a list of them.

 

Upcoming Certificate Expiration

In case there are any certificates where their expiration date is coming up in the next 90 days, they will be listed in this chapter to notify about this early on.

 

 

Do you want to learn more on how to find and use the security relevant content in the SAP EarlyWatch Alert Workspace? Then check out this blog for more information.

Stay tuned for more content regarding Security in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition systems to be added to the SAP EarlyWatch Alert! 🚀

entry.title: A Practical Guide to Cost Center APIs in SAP S/4HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Introduction

When working with cost center master data in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, we often encounter the need to use different APIs. Depending on the scenario, there can be several options available to integrate, replicate, or maintain cost center data.

At first glance, it may seem straightforward to simply use an API. However, the reality is more complex. cost center provides multiple API options, each designed with its own strengths, limitations, and typical use cases.

This blog post aims to bring more clarity by walking through the different API options available for cost center in the public cloud context. We will start by explaining some core concepts, such as the difference between synchronous and asynchronous APIs, and how to think about inbound and outbound APIs. Later, we will look into the individual technologies and provide guidance on how to choose the right API for your use case.

 

Synchronous vs. Asynchronous APIs

One of the most fundamental distinctions when talking about APIs is whether they are synchronous or asynchronous.

  • Synchronous APIs:
    A synchronous API works like a phone call. You “dial” the API, send a request, and wait for the response. You know immediately whether the operation succeeded or failed. This approach is great for real-time validation, single record maintenance, and interactive applications.
  • Asynchronous APIs:
    An asynchronous API is more like sending a letter or an email. You send the request, and the system processes it in the background. The response may come later, often through a callback, message, or event. This approach is better suited for bulk operations, replication, or integrations where immediate feedback is not required.

In practice, you will often integrate APIs into workflows. A useful guideline is to stick to one type of API in your workflow. Mixing synchronous and asynchronous calls can introduce complexity, especially if you need to coordinate responses.

For example:

  • Starting with an asynchronous request and then immediately relying on a synchronous call without checking status may fail because the data is not yet processed.
  • If you must combine them, always build in the right checks: confirm the asynchronous process is complete before moving to the synchronous step.

Examples: How to work with synchronous/asynchronous APIs

  • If your process needs an instant response, such as validation or single master data change — go for synchronous.
  • If your process deals with large volumes or can wait for processing — asynchronous is usually more efficient.

 

Inbound vs. Outbound APIs

Another useful way of categorizing APIs is to look at whether they are inbound or outbound:

  • Inbound APIs: These are used when an external system wants to send data to an SAP S/4HANA system. In the cost center context, this could mean creating, updating, or deleting cost center master data from an external application.
  • Outbound APIs: These are used when an SAP S/4HANA system sends data or events to an external system. In other words, these APIs “push” information out.

 

Technologies

Working with cost center master data comes with different integration needs, and SAP offers a variety of API technologies to meet them. Each option is designed for specific scenarios and scope items, so choosing the right API depends on your particular requirements. In the sections below, we provide an overview of the key technologies available in SAP S/4HANA Cloud and how they are typically used.

OData V4:

The Cost Center OData V4 service allows you to create, read, update, and delete cost center master data directly in your system. Since it is an inbound, synchronous API, it is designed for real-time interactions where you need immediate feedback on your changes. The service is built on the RESTful ABAP Programming Model (RAP), which ensures it follows modern development principles and supports extensibility. This means you can adapt the data model and business logic to meet your specific requirements without losing compatibility during system upgrades. Typical scenarios for using this API include creating or updating cost centers from external applications or interactive user interfaces, where instant validation and confirmation are important.

🔗 OData V4 cost center API on API Hub

Business Object Extensibility (Steampunk API)

For developers working on SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform), the cost center business object  Steampunk APIs provide another way to interact with cost center master data. These APIs are also inbound and synchronous, making them suitable for real-time updates. 

🔗Steampunk API on API Hub

OData V2 Read APIs

In some cases, you only need read-only access to cost center data.  OData V2 Read APIs  (A2X services ) provide synchronous access to this information, enabling external systems to retrieve data in real time without modifying it. This is useful for reporting, monitoring, or any scenarios where up-to-date cost center information is required for external applications.

🔗OData V2 Read cost center API on API Hub

Business Events

When your goal is to react to changes rather than actively pull data, Business Events are the way to go. These are outbound, meaning S/4HANA pushes notifications to subscribing systems whenever a relevant change occurs. By subscribing to cost center events, a workflow or external application can respond immediately, for example by fetching updated details or triggering additional processes. This event-driven approach is particularly useful for keeping external systems in sync with S/4HANA or automating business processes based on changes in master data.

🔗 Cost center Business Events on API Hub

SOAP API

As the name suggests, this API transfers the request via SOAP protocol. SOAP API CostCentreReplicationBulkRequest_In is an inbound, asynchronous API that can be used for cost center replication into your S/4HANA system. As it is based on asynchronous processing, it is suitable for changes that do not require immediate response. Usage of SOAP APIs in workflows is generally not advised, unless they perform the final operation or an operation that is not prerequisite for a follow-up step.

 🔗 SOAP cost center API on API Hub 

 

How to choose an API that suits you best

While there are many scenarios where you can use cost center APIs. This little breakdown gives you an idea of which technology to use for each case. Whiie various APIs can support certain scenarios, we highlight the ones that offer the best capabilities for the given task.

 

Combining different APIs in a single workflow

Earlier, we have outlined the importance of taking caution when working with different technologies in a single workflow. This is especially true if a synchronous API and an asynchronous API coexist in the same stack. Let’s explore possible scenarios and their potential challenges.

Combining Synchronous and Asynchronous APIs

There are multiple systems that can carry out cost center changes. Each system, when the change or creation happens, sends a request to the consolidation system that collects all changes from all systems in the landscape and consolidates them. Periodically, this system returns the consolidated data to the source systems for replication and sends them also to receiver systems.

  • If this is done on a time basis, for example, the replication is triggered every midnight, there is no significance whether the replication is carried out synchronously or asynchronously.
  • But if there is a condition in place, for example when the replication is triggered after every change request, then the importance of choosing the right technology is essential.

Asynchronous APIs and Their Challenges

If you send a change request via a SOAP API (asynchronous), you would get an immediate response of HTTP status 200, which simply means that the request was accepted, not that the processing is complete. This is often confused as a response to the request being carried out, which is not exactly true. The request was only accepted and (apart from subscription to business event), there is no further notification of a successful completion. It’s important to keep in mind this distinction:

  • If you misinterpret the initial HTTP response as confirmation of successful processing and use it as a trigger for the replication, you could potentially replicate outdated data, as carrying out the change takes time and is dependent on system resources available.
  • It is also unreliable to choose an arbitrary wait time and then follow up with replication.

The only way to ensure proper synchronization is to trigger an additional GET request, verifying you have the expected data in the system. Or you can avoid this hassle by simply carrying out a synchronous request via OData API. Successful response in a synchronous API means that the request is completed in full and the data is processed and persisted. This can safely serve as a trigger condition for your further processing.

Combining APIs and Business Events

Let’s describe a different scenario where a combination of a business event and an OData API provide a more fluid and efficient integration of a simple workflow. When a cost center is changed in a system, the system implicitly triggers a business event. If there is a listener active, other system can receive this signal with a payload and act according to the desired logic. The payload only consists of the key fields, so when the system recognizes this data as necessary for further processing, it may send an OData GET request to the provider system to retrieve the full data set and persist changes.

 

Conclusion

This post provides a clear overview of the various APIs available for managing cost center master data in SAP S/4HANA Cloud. By understanding the differences between synchronous and asynchronous APIs, inbound and outbound communication, and the specific applications of technologies like OData V4, SOAP, and Business Events, you can choose the most suitable option for your integration needs. Using the right API technology thoughtfully can simplify workflows, ensure data accuracy, and optimize system efficiency. With these insights, you are well-prepared to make the most of the capabilities each API offers while avoiding challenges in complex integrations.

entry.title: Next Generation Just-In-Time, Supply to Customer
entry.content:
The Next Generation JIT Processing solution is now available in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud (Supply to Customer).

 JIT Supply to Customer(S2C) allows you to run just-in-time process with your customer for products delivered from stock or manufactured based on JIT requests. You can receive and process delivery schedules with reference to JIT sales scheduling agreements for planning and production purposes and receive summarized or sequenced JIT calls for shipping purposes. The Next Generation JIT S2C provide bellow business value:

  • Supports the basic business process for just-in-time supply
  • Provides efficiency and transparency in processing
  • Helps process the supply efficiently
  • Flexibility through configuration and extensibility

Let’s take the business of automobile industry as an example, JIT S2C solution will be used on the supply business between Component Manufacturer and Vehicle Manufacturer.

There are two types of JIT Call: Summarized JIT Call and Sequenced JIT Call.

Summarized JIT Call is quantity-based or container-based call-offs without vehicle reference.

Sequenced JIT Call is Order-based requests for supply in sequence of production with Vehicle-specific (reference to VIN/production number).

Let’s focus on Sequenced JIT Call and deep dive further.

From the above lifecycle figure of the Sequenced JIT Calls, you can see that:

  • We start the process from manage customer request by creating Customer JIT Calls. Most of the time JIT Calls will be created via EDI, but manually creating JIT Calls also be supported.
  • If you supply to customer with production, you release JIT Calls to production and confirm production with related goods movements posted.
  • After the manufactured products been received to stock, you pack the products and create outbound deliveries. Post goods issue to the outbound deliveries.
  • Create and process billing document from customer.

We support Monitoring JIT Calls by Internal Processing Status like below. You can easily figure out how many JIT Calls are there and which status they are in.

Overall, next-generation JIT processing in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition provides a robust framework for managing complex supply chain operations, offering significant advantages in terms of efficiency, flexibility, and transparency.

entry.title: What’s New in SAP Central Business Configuration 2506 FD2
entry.content:
With the latest release for SAP Central Business Configuration, an exciting new feature is available. This blog post will provide you with a concise overview.

Enhanced Transparency for Initial Scoping

We’re excited to announce that you can now quickly identify scenarios that are only selectable during initial scoping, all without leaving SAP Central Business Configuration. In the Define Scope app, the new Selection Allowed filter lets you display scenarios that can only be added initially, not later. This provides clarity on the scope decisions you need to make before confirming your scope for the first time.

Selection Allowed filter in the Define Scope app

For a quick summary, check out this video about What's New in 2506 FD2. Don’t forget to also use the What’s New Viewer on the SAP Help Portal, which provides further details and links about all the recent changes.

That wraps up the new features this time. Did you like this blog? If so, please leave us a thumbs up at the top. Also, make sure to follow the SAP Central Business Configuration tag or follow this dedicated blog collection to stay up to date with the latest blog posts.

Do you have any ideas on how to further enhance SAP Central Business Configuration? Go to the Customer Influence platform to submit an improvement request or vote for the ideas of others. This helps us understand your requirements even better and prioritize our work accordingly. We’re looking forward to your improvement requests.

entry.title: Artificial Intelligence and SAP Master Data Governance
entry.content:
It is a no brainer that high-speed availability of elevated quality data is crucial in state-of-the-art master data processing. Therefore, SAP Master Data Governance addresses this topic for quite a while with features like: 

  • ML-based rule mining  
  • derivation of field values  
  • data provider integration for the automated take-over of proven reference data from 3rd party data providers and 
  • most recently with the integration of generative AI 

AI is a game changer in many fields, and therefore I’d like to shed light on its ever increasing impact on master data processing.

The Impact of AI on Master Data Governance: A New Era of Intelligent Data Management

In today’s digital economy, data is more than just an asset - it’s the foundation of business intelligence, compliance, and operational success. Among the many types of enterprise data, master data - including customer, vendor, and product data - plays a central role in ensuring consistency and accuracy across systems. However, managing and governing this data has traditionally been a complex, manual, and error-prone process.

With the rise of Artificial Intelligence (AI), master data governance is undergoing an additional transformation. AI brings speed, intelligence, and automation to data governance processes, enabling organizations to maintain high data quality standards while significantly reducing manual effort and cost. AI benefits are in the hands of Master Data Management business users as they will be empowered using functions in SAP Master Data Governance, without additional tools and training and with increased flexibility and ease governing business partner data in future.

Challenges of Ungoverned Master Data

Organizations that rely on ungoverned master data practices face numerous challenges:

  • Manual data entry is prone to human error and inconsistencies across departments and systems.
  • Duplicate or outdated records compromise decision-making and customer experience.
  • Global data compliance requirements make it harder to enforce consistent rules and formats.

These challenges can lead to poor data quality, inefficiencies, and even financial and reputational risks.

AI’s Transformational Role in Master Data Management

AI has the potential to enhance every aspect of master data governance. From automating routine tasks to predicting and preventing errors, AI can enable organizations to transition from reactive data management to proactive data stewardship. This includes the following aspects:

Data Quality and Cleansing

AI algorithms could automatically identify missing, incomplete, or inconsistent data. For example, if a product entry lacks a critical attribute, AI can detect the issue and either correct it or flag it for review. Natural Language Processing (NLP) helps interpret unstructured data, enabling organizations to extract and standardize information from disparate sources.

Intelligent Matching and Deduplication

AI excels at fuzzy matching, which is critical for identifying duplicate records that may not be exact matches. Whether it's variations in customer names, addresses, or product codes, AI learns from historical corrections to improve deduplication over time, even across different languages or local conventions.

Predictive Data Governance

AI could proactively monitor data entry patterns and detect anomalies before they create downstream problems. For instance, if a vendor record deviates from standard formats or contains unusual combinations of data, AI can suggest corrections or flag it for review.

Workflow Automation and Smart Approvals

AI could optimize approval workflows by learning from past decisions and routing requests to the right people automatically. This reduces the cycle time for master data changes and ensures compliance with governance policies without unnecessary delays.

Data Steward Assistance

Data stewards benefit from AI acting as a co-pilot - suggesting actions, prioritizing issues, and providing insights. AI-powered chatbots or virtual assistants can help them query records, update data, or perform validations faster and more accurately.

Current scope and trends in SAP Master Data Governance

 SAP MDG has started embedding AI and machine learning into its framework to enhance data quality and governance automation. Please read following recent articles for a clearer picture: 

  • Inclusion of Generative AI in MDG (as of SAP S/4HANA 2023 Cloud Private Edition Feature Pack Stack 02) 
    used for summary of changes and assisted changes in central governance (classic mode), and for optional business partner processing (in cloud-ready mode) initiated by a Joule dialog. 
  • Gen AI-based assisted change for custom objects and summary of mass changes (as of SAP S/4HANA 2023 Cloud Private Edition Feature Pack Stack 03) 
    AI-assisted changes in central governance for reuse entities in custom objects and AI-based summary of change requests with multiple objects (mass changes). 
  • Master Data Governance Facilitating Generative AI 
    Blog post on how generative AI impacts master data management and vice versa. 

The AI-enabled SAP Joule assistant utilizes natural language processing to allow employees to execute professional Master Data Governance tasks, such as updating business partner information and checking governance workflows, without needing deep MDG expertise. To get the full picture of planned AI innovations in SAP Master Data Governance across the entire MDG solution portfolio, see the SAP Roadmap Explorer.

And finally, I would also like to refer to the following planned AI Webinar: Upcoming MDM Webinar (October 15th) with the Hackett Group

This webinar is with The Hackett Group and focused on the recent Hackett Group World Class Matrix for MDM Software, in which SAP participated. It is a live, interactive webinar, that will journey through the evolution of Master Data Management (MDM) – from its foundational role in process improvement to its impact on analytical and AI outcomes. We will wrap up with a summary of the capabilities of SAP Master Data Governance for operational excellence and accurate analytics and AI as well as discuss how AI within MDM is driving new value.

The registration page is available here: https://event.on24.com/wcc/r/5071369/89EF715DACF727EA399DE330113B0340. 

The impact is measurable: reduced manual effort, fewer data errors, and improved compliance.

Additional Considerations going forward

AI holds great promise for the future, following considerations shall always be kept in mind:

  • Data bias: AI models will have to be trained on diverse and accurate datasets to avoid reinforcing existing biases. MDG can provide proper basis for this.
  • Data privacy: Organizations must ensure that AI respects privacy laws like GDPR and CCPA when processing sensitive master data.
  • Model transparency: AI decisions, such as why a record was flagged or approved, must be explainable and auditable.
  • Human oversight: AI should augment - not replace - human governance. Final decisions should remain with accountable physical persons.

The benefit lies in the strong hand in hand co-work of proven master data governance augmented by AI innovation aspects.

Conclusion

AI has the potential to revolutionize master data governance by making it smarter, faster, and more proactive. By automating manual processes, improving data quality, and enhancing governance workflows. AI empowers organizations to manage their most critical data assets with greater agility and confidence with one stop-shop - Joule.

As businesses strive for digital transformation, adopting AI in MDG is not just a technological upgrade - it’s a strategic imperative. The organizations that embrace this shift now will be the ones that lead in data-driven innovation tomorrow.

As AI technologies mature, organizations will move from data maintenance to intelligent data orchestration - turning governance into a strategic advantage.

I hope this information sharing about Joule insights within MDG is interesting for you to read. If you enjoyed this article, be sure to subscribe and leave us a review. Until next time, keep innovating and stay curious! 

To stay on track, simply follow the SAP Community Topic Page for SAP Master Data Governance, read the MDG-related blogs, and join the  Q&A forum. 

Best, 
Ria

entry.title: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management: Q3-25 Updates & Highlights
entry.content:
In the past quarter, we continued delivering many more useful features and functions in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, and we achieved great success stories together with our customers. This blog post continues my quarterly series and gives you an overview of some of the highlights. In this edition, I’m covering:

  • ERP-Centric Transport Footprint Calculation
  • Manage Footprint Results – Source Input Items
  • GHG Data Collection API and SAP Build Process Automation
  • Onboarding Booster
  • Other Release Highlights
  • Customer Success Stories: KNAPP & Tyrolit
  • Upcoming Partner Webinars
  • Additional Information

 

ERP-Centric Transport Footprint Calculation

Transportation can be a major contributor to Scope 3 emissions, yet calculating its impact has mostly been complex and manual. With the new ERP‑centric transport footprint calculation, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management introduces a capability that leverages your existing ERP master and transactional data to automate and scale transport emission calculations. This means you can move from spreadsheets and estimates to actual, auditable results that integrate seamlessly into both corporate and product carbon footprints.

Instead of building transport models from scratch, the solution now derives upstream and internal transport activities from Goods Receipt from Supplier, Goods Return to Supplier, and Goods Transfer data, and then calculates the footprint per activity, route, and leg. In practical terms, a transport activity is determined as the movement of specific products in given quantities between two locations under defined conditions. The system brings together master data, transaction details, and transport settings to identify source and target locations, the mode of transport, and whether goods move under ambient or temperature-controlled conditions. It then builds optimal transport routes via connection points such as airports, seaports, inland ports, and railway stations, before applying the relevant emission factors to calculate the footprint.

 

In the following, I’ll briefly summarize the required process steps and introduce the new apps. For detailed information, see Calculating Transport Footprints Using Business Transactions.

To use the new approach, start with importing transport-relevant master data, so routing and distances work out-of-the-box. Products now carry a Custom Temperature Condition, and SAP provides a default mapping to Ambient. If you need temperature-controlled transport, create your own custom conditions and map them to the standard values (Ambient or Temperature-Controlled). Locations and Plants now support addresses and geo-coordinates, and Business Partners can be imported with Supplier and Carrier roles, including address data tied to supplier IDs.

Then you can configure your inventory scope and in Transport Details set the Data Source to Standard (Business Transactions). Newly created scopes default to Standard, while existing scopes remain on Classic until you switch them.

For maintaining transport connection points – like seaports, inland ports, airports, railway stations – go to the Manage Locations app, where you already find SAP-delivered content for seaports and airports to help kick-start sea and air routes.

Next, configure how goods typically move in your network with the new Manage Transport Settings app. Define haul types and distances – short haul defaults to 1500 km and can be adapted – and specify the primary mode of transport from supplier locations to one or all plants, optionally by product group. The same supplier-to-plant mode applies to returns back to the supplier. For internal logistics, create directional settings for movements between plants.

With settings in place, use the new Manage Transport Activities app to generate transport activities for your chosen scope and period from the ERP transactions. Once activities are clean, generate the corresponding routes and legs. In case of inconsistencies, the app guides you with messages helping you to resolve before calculation.

Emission factors for the different modes of transport are managed in the new Manage Transport Operation Footprints app, and you can maintain them in the UI directly or import via file.

Finally, run the transport calculation in the new Calculate Transport Footprints app and review results per activity, route, and leg.

In the Calculate Footprints app, the Data Readiness tab lists transport data as one of the data types. Transport is now a first-class citizen across the analytics experience. In organizational footprint inventories, transport data becomes mandatory whenever your scope uses Standard and transport-relevant value chain steps are enabled. Transport footprints are created as input items to products, if a carrier is specified, the corresponding business partner footprint is used as the utilized item, otherwise the input is shown as Unknown Carrier. You can see transport-related product and business partner items in the Manage Footprint Results app, and analyze Scope 3.4 emissions in depth in the Footprint Overview app.

A quick note on provisioning: The new apps require explicit role assignment, role names are case-sensitive, and write access requires both read and write roles. If you’re moving from the classic transport approach, reimport your enhanced master data for Plants, Business Partners, Products, and relevant Locations via file or API, then switch your inventory scopes to Standard (Business Transactions). Keep scopes on Classic if you plan to recalculate them using the classic transport apps. With these pieces in place, the new transport calculation streamlines data preparation, strengthens routing fidelity, and brings transport emissions seamlessly into your product and corporate footprint story.

 

Manage Footprint Results – Source Input Items

For decarbonizing your company and products, it’s crucial to have full transparency into what’s actually driving emissions across the value chain. While total product footprints are useful, they often leave a critical question unanswered: Where exactly do these emissions come from? Without that level of granularity, it’s difficult to identify hotspots, prioritize reduction efforts, or make informed decisions that lead to real impact. To address this, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management now includes a new feature in the Manage Footprint Results app: Source Input Items. This enhancement gives you a detailed view into the specific inputs that contribute to a product’s environmental footprint – enabling smarter, data-driven strategies for decarbonization.

 

Source input items represent the materials, energy, transport, and other resources used at the start of a process that result in emissions. With just a click on Generate, you can now explore these contributors for each footprint item (excluding items of type business partner, work in progress, production documents, and supplier). Note that source input items currently cannot yet be generated for calculation results involving cycles, this will be added in a future release.

The app provides you with various charts that instantly visualize emissions across lifecycle stages such as material acquisition, production, transport, and end-of-life treatment. These charts help you pinpoint the most emission-intensive stages and align your analysis with the GHG Protocol. You can also customize the view to match your specific reporting or decision-making needs. Below the chart, a consolidated table provides full transparency into each source input item.

With this enhancement, SAP Sustainability Footprint Management strengthens its role as an intuitive product fact sheet, empowering you to go beyond high-level metrics. You can now trace emissions to their source, understand their context, and take targeted action – whether that means switching suppliers, optimizing logistics, or redesigning products. For all information, see Viewing the Footprint Results on SAP Help.

 

GHG Data Collection API and SAP Build Process Automation

One of the recurring challenges in tracking greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions is the complexity and scale of data collection. Sustainability teams often need to gather activity and spend data from various business units, geographies, or partner organizations. To address these hurdles, we now released the GHG Data Forms API. This new public API empowers you to extend and tailor the GHG data collection process far beyond the core application: External workflows, survey applications, or even mobile apps can now retrieve, maintain, and push data directly into the GHG Data Forms in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. By decentralizing and parallelizing how and where environmental data is gathered, you can drive faster, more automated, and more consistent emission data capture across your full operational or organizational boundary. For technical details and integration guidelines, refer to the official API documentation on SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

One powerful example of leveraging this API is through SAP Build Process Automation. With SAP Build workflows, you can automate and streamline sustainability data collection across multiple locations. The process begins by triggering a workflow, either manually or on a scheduled basis, then retrieving all relevant business activities and locations from SAP Sustainability Footprint Management using the API. Through parallel subprocesses for each location, you can enable simultaneous data collection and significantly reduce cycle time. Business users receive customizable forms – survey-style via SAP Build or ticket-style via SAP Task Center – delivered directly to the right people based on responsibility rules, with built-in notifications and reminders to keep the process moving. Once data is submitted, it’s routed for approval, and after validation, posted back to SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and included into the overall footprint calculation. This approach provides flexibility, scalability, and compliance, helping sustainability teams focus on insights rather than manual tasks.

 

 

Onboarding Booster

With the introduction of the Onboarding Booster, we’re speeding up the time required for setting up am SAP Sustainability Footprint Management tenant on SAP BTP. The entire onboarding can now be completed in about 10 to 15 minutes through a guided, automated process. The booster is integrated into the SAP BTP cockpit and walks you through the essential steps: checking prerequisites, selecting the identity service, and either creating or choosing a subaccount. Once these steps are confirmed, the system takes over and performs the necessary configurations in the background. The result is a fully prepared environment that is ready for role assignment and productive use. This is more than just a time saver, it reduces complexity and lowers the barrier for customers to get started quickly and confidently. For detailed guidance, the full procedure is documented in our Help Portal: Setting Up Using Booster.

 

Other Release Highlights

We’ve redesigned the SAP Fiori Launchpad Structure for a more intuitive experience. New app groups offer logical organization, simplifying navigation and helping you to quickly find what you need. For more information, see Enhanced SAP Fiori Launchpad Structure.

You can now assign different location types (not just plants) to a single business activity, expanding flexibility, supporting more accurate form generation, and ensuring that business activities can be valid across multiple locations. See Creating Business Activities for more information.

Additionally, when setting your footprint inventory scope, plant assignments now ensure that only relevant forms are generated for your selected companies and locations. This prevents the creation of irrelevant forms, enhancing efficiency and streamlining the data collection process. Learn more here: Creating Business Activities.

 

Customer Success Stories

KNAPP AG, a global leader in intralogistics and warehouse automation, faced new challenges with the EU’s Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD), which raised the bar for ESG transparency. Instead of waiting for deadlines, KNAPP acted early, building a strong sustainability data foundation with SAP Sustainability solutions. Partnering with KPMG Austria, KNAPP implemented SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Control Tower to replace manual reporting with automated, integrated processes. These solutions consolidated over 200 sustainability metrics from across the business, delivering advanced carbon footprint calculations at both product and corporate levels. This gave KNAPP unprecedented visibility into emissions, resource use, and overall ESG impact. With audit-ready reporting in place, KNAPP achieved CSRD compliance well ahead of schedule and embedded sustainability insights into daily operations and strategic planning. This proactive approach turned compliance into a catalyst for transformation, accelerating their “now4tomorrow” program and ensuring their first sustainability report complements financial disclosures. Read the full story: Getting ahead of regulatory reporting to steer business process transformation.

Tyrolit is a global leader in abrasive tools and construction systems that operates across 48 companies and exports to 140+ countries. Also facing growing demands for transparent ESG reporting under CSRD, Tyrolit needed to move beyond fragmented systems and spreadsheets that made standardization and auditability difficult. To address this, Tyrolit deployed SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Control Tower, integrated via SAP Business Technology Platform. This centralized ESG data collection from SAP and third-party systems, aligned sustainability reporting with financial standards, and enabled advanced analytics for benchmarking and target setting. AI-powered automation reduced manual work, improved accuracy, and provided dashboards for 60+ managers to monitor 80+ ESG metrics. This resulted in measurable carbon reductions, less plastic packaging, and higher recycling rates. Tyrolit now uses data-driven insights to identify emission-saving opportunities and embed sustainability across the organization. Check the full story: Tooling up to unlock the sustainable value chain with a robust ESG data foundation.

 

Upcoming Partner Webinars

Staying ahead means staying informed, and this quarter again brings two opportunities exclusively for our partners to connect and learn more about SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. Both webinars are free for partners with a valid SAP Learning Hub license.

The SAP Business Suite Product Expert Training is a biannual event designed to empower partners with in-depth product know-how, practical guidance, and the latest innovations across SAP Cloud ERP, the SAP Business Suite, AI-powered features, and more. On October 10, you can learn more about the latest updates in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, SAP Sustainability Control Tower, and SAP Sustainability Data Exchange. Register for the session here: Sustainability Management and Carbon Accounting. For an overview of all sessions and their respective registration links check out: SAP Business Suite Product Expert Training 2025.

On November 5, the Meet the Expert Session returns. This highly interactive webinar is your chance to bring questions directly to the SAP experts from the Product Management and Customer Adoption teams. Gain practical insights, obtain answers to your questions, and deepen your expertise in SAP Sustainability Footprint Management. Register here: SAP Sustainability Footprint Management - Meet the Expert Q4 2025.

 

Additional Information

To learn more on how you can enhance the accuracy of your Scope 3.1 emissions reporting by transitioning from broad average data to precise, supplier-specific actuals, you should check out the blog post Implementing an Average to Actuals Strategy for Scope 3.1 by @CButzlaff. This article outlines a practical, phased approach for implementing this strategy using SAP Sustainability Footprint Management and SAP Sustainability Data Exchange.

For a comprehensive guide on how to embed carbon accounting into your ERP and finance processes, have a look into the new SAP PRESS book Carbon Accounting for Sustainability with SAP. It explains how to capture sustainability data across your ERP landscape, calculate product- and company-level carbon footprints, and integrate results into finance through SAP Green Ledger. You’ll also learn how SAP Sustainability Data Exchange and SAP Sustainability Footprint Management enable accurate, auditable carbon data for decision-making and reporting.

For in-depth details on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, including concepts, setup, and the application help, I recommend you browsing through the SAP Help Portal. For an overview of all new features and functions that have been released, check the What’s New section, which is updated with every new software release.

For exploring and experimenting in a live system, register for the free SAP Sustainability Footprint Management Trial. You’ll receive an e-mail with access information within seconds after your registration and can then test the solution at your own convenience within a 30-day trial period. It also includes a wide range of guided tours designed to help you navigate through all the features and functions comprehensively. Recently, we also added new tours and will shortly release additional ones, representing the latest features and an enhanced user experience.

To stay up to date on SAP Sustainability Footprint Management, follow me here in the SAP Community. In regular cadence, I’ll publish blog posts giving you updates on all the product’s new features and functions as well as deep dives into the product capabilities. I’m also looking forward to engaging with you directly, feel free to leave your feedback in the comment section.

entry.title: AI-Powered Dispute Management with SAP Enterprise Service Management (ESM) and S/4HANA Cloud
entry.content:
In today’s fast-paced business environment, handling customer invoice disputes efficiently is critical to maintaining trust and improving financial operations. SAP Enterprise Service Management (ESM), when integrated with FI-AR Dispute Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, brings automation, AI, and seamless connectivity to streamline the entire process.

What is SAP S/4HANA Dispute Management?

Dispute Management is a subcomponent of SAP S/4HANA Financial Supply Chain Management (FSCM). It enables businesses to record, monitor, and resolve disputes related to customer invoices. With features such as workflow-driven case management, audit trails, and integration to accounts receivable, it ensures that every dispute is handled systematically and efficiently.

Key benefits include:

  • Centralized tracking of disputes
  • Improved collaboration between finance, sales, and customer service teams
  • Automated workflows for faster approvals and escalations
  • Enhanced reporting for dispute trends and root cause analysis

Role of Enterprise Service Management (ESM)

While SAP manages financial disputes effectively, many organizations struggle with cross-functional coordination. That’s where ESM comes in. ESM extends the principles of IT Service Management (ITSM) into business domains like Finance, HR, Procurement, and Customer Service.

By integrating SAP Dispute Management with an ESM platform (such as ServiceNow or SAP’s own service management tools), organizations gain:

  • Unified Service Portal: Customers, sales teams, and service agents can log, track, and monitor disputes through a single interface.
  • Automated Ticketing & Routing: Disputes raised in ESM automatically create dispute cases in SAP S/4HANA, ensuring seamless data flow.
  • Real-Time Updates: Resolution progress is synchronized between SAP and the ESM tool, reducing the need for manual follow-ups.

Quick summary of the flow

  • Customer sends email
  • ESM (case management) auto-creates a case
  • AI/OCR extracts invoice number, disputed amount, reason, attachments
  • Validate / enrich by looking up open receivables in S/4HANA
  • Create a formal Dispute record in S/4HANA (tie back to the ESM case)
  • Track, collaborate, resolve and close (sync statuses both ways)

Prerequisites

To enable this end-to-end process, organizations require:

  • An SAP S/4HANA system with FI-AR Dispute Management
  • An Enterprise Service Management platform (e.g., SAP ESM or ServiceNow)
  • A middleware/integration layer such as SAP Cloud Platform Integration (CPI)
  • Document extraction capabilities for AI/OCR-based data capture

End-to-End Process Flow

The integrated dispute process can be summarized in six steps (as shown in the flow):

 

 

 

1. Customer raises a dispute via email
A customer initiates contact by sending an email to the company’s shared dispute mailbox (e.g., disputes@company.com). The email may highlight issues such as overcharges, incorrect quantities, or pricing discrepancies and typically includes details like the invoice number, disputed amount, and reason for the dispute.

2. Case Creation

Once the email is received, SAP Enterprise Service Management automatically creates a case and assigns it to the appropriate case type. The system can also categorize the case and route it to the right support team without manual intervention.

3. Information Extraction

Artificial intelligence extracts key details from the email—such as invoice number, disputed amount, and reason for dispute—converting unstructured text into structured business information that can be used downstream.

4. Lookup Receivable Items

The system then connects to the FI-AR module in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Using the extracted invoice number, it fetches the relevant receivable items. This information is automatically linked to the case, where agents can review and validate it.

5. Create Dispute in SAP S/4HANA

From the case details page, the service agent can create a dispute in SAP S/4HANA Cloud with a single click. The dispute case references the correct invoice, associates the appropriate dispute reason and amount, and links it to the relevant customer master data.

 

6. Case Tracking & Resolution

Through ESM, both internal teams and customers can track the progress of the dispute. Notifications, escalations, and collaboration features ensure timely resolution.

Business Value of SAP S/4HANA + ESM Integration

  • Faster Dispute Resolution: Reduces cycle time by eliminating manual handoffs.
  • Customer Satisfaction: Improves transparency and trust with real-time status visibility.
  • Operational Efficiency: Automates repetitive tasks, freeing teams to focus on high-value work.
  • Data-Driven Insights: Helps organizations identify recurring issues and fix root cause

Conclusion

Integrating SAP S/4HANA Dispute Management with ESM bridges the gap between finance operations and customer-facing services. It transforms dispute resolution from a siloed, manual process into a collaborative, automated, and transparent workflow. For organizations looking to enhance customer experience while safeguarding cash flow, this integration is not just a technical upgrade — it’s a strategic move toward financial resilience and service excellence.

In short: Disputes don’t have to be disruptions — with S/4HANA and ESM, they can become opportunities for service excellence.

entry.title: Preliminary What’s New Information for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.2
entry.content:
Preliminary version of What’s New information and of the Product Assistance are now available for customers and partners to get a preview on the upcoming new and changed features of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.2.

You can find this preview on the current SAP Help Portal page SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition (see What’s New section “Preview of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.2”). To access the Preliminary What’s New information, please use the What’s New Viewer or the Release Assessment and Scope Dependency (RASD) tool.

The RASD tool provides you with a personalized and tailored view on What’s New information based on the activated and used scope within your system. The preliminary information for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.2 will be available in RASD within the next few days. We recommend using RASD to prepare for upgrades and updates of your system and to focus on the new and changed features that are relevant for you. A valid S-User ID is needed to use the RASD tool and to view all the preliminary content stated above.

For any feedback you may have, try the Commenting Feature for What's New documentation in this release. See this blog for more information.

entry.title: GRC, Trade and Tax with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
With this blog I will walk you through the selected key highlights for Governance, Risk, Compliance (GRC), Trade and Tax in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508:

In case you do not need all the information and just briefly want to get an overview of the release highlights, please watch the video below:

 
Video #1: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 GRC

This blog covers the following innovations:

SAP Risk and Assurance Management

  • Preconfigured business content to detect fraud and money laundering transactions (SAP Risk and Assurance Management)
  • Overview pages for controls
  • Overview pages for risks

SAP Document and Reporting Compliance

  • Statutory reporting: mass action and scheduling
  • Malaysia e-invoicing: exchange of electronic invoices through the Peppol network
  • India Goods and services tax (GST) reporting - GSTR-1, GSTR-2A and GSTR-3B
  • Accelerated electronic document corrections with GenAI

SAP International Trade Management

  • Cloud BAdIs for Intrastat (BDT)
  • Localization option for Intrastat (BDT)
  • New compliance status for purchase orders
  • Trade classification proposals for custom tariff numbers and commodity codes
  • Audit trail for Watch List Screening

SAP Risk and Assurance Management

Preconfigured business content to detect fraud and money laundering transactions (SAP Risk and Assurance Management)

Fig #1 : preconfigured business content to detect fraud and money laundering transactions

SAP Risk and Assurance Management comes with predefined business content that you can use of the box, such as predefined automated procedures and controls, to minimize the effort of building your financial compliance management framework.

Value Proposition

  • Speed up usage with predefined business content for detection rules
  • Enable finance departments to detect fraud or suspicious payments

Capabilities

  • New automated procedures with a focus on anti-money laundering and fraud:
    • High-risk country incoming payments
      • Check incoming payments against list of countries or regions deemed to be high-risk
    • Payer name deviation in incoming payments
      • Check incoming payments against transferring vendor name.
    • Postings on expense accounts
    • Outgoing payments on expense accounts
    • IBAN deviations in incoming payments
    • Customer negative amount postings by user
    • Customer negative amount postings by ratio

For more information, see: Business Content for SAP Risk and Assurance Management

Overview pages for controls

 

Video #2: Demo Overview Page

This Overview page is designed to help our Compliance Managers save time by effectively monitoring progress & getting an instant overview that no critical control runs are missed and helping him quickly identifying and analyzing errors in work packages.

Value Proposition

  • Centralised information hub
  • Improved decision making through real time monitoring
  • Profit from early awareness and proactive operations

Capabilities

  • Operational dashboard for the compliance manager to get an overview of controls and work packages of the organisation
  • Overview on control performance results in time intervals, by control risk level and significance and  work packages by procedure run status
  • Ability to navigate to the specific risk from the overview page

For more information, see: Controls Analytics

Overview pages for risk management

Fig #2 : overview pages for risk management

A risk heat map is an important tool for a risk manager helping them identify, prioritize, and address risks, as well as communicate about risks with stakeholders.

Value Proposition

  • Gain real-time risk visibility
  • Improve the efficiency of the risk manager
  • Profit from early awareness and proactive risk management

Capabilities

  • Visualised dashboard that helps risk managers gain insights into the overall risk status of the organization
  • Heatmaps showing the current risk landscape
  • View risks by different dimensions, such as organization unit, risk category, and so on
  • Ability to navigate to the specific risk from the overview page

For more information, see: Risk Overview

SAP Document and Reporting Compliance

Statutory reporting: mass action and scheduling

 

Video #3:  Statutory reporting: mass action and scheduling

Schedule Mass Action enables you to automate the generation of multiple report runs simultaneously and set them to recur at desired intervals. This feature is beneficial for streamlining reporting processes, saving time, and ensuring consistency in report generation.

Mass Action now also supports trigger of workflow approvals and submission of report runs electronically.

The Update Reporting Tasks feature allows you to instantly update specific reporting tasks for a desired reporting year through the reports dashboard.

A new submission status has now been introduced for the processing of runs with large volumes of documents. When a run involves more than 100 documents, the status will now display as Submission In Progress.

Benefits

  • Automate the approval and submission process, improving overall efficiency
  • Automate and schedule report generation, helping ensure consistency, improving efficiency, and reducing errors
  • Provide flexible options for defining report generation schedules
  • Improve efficiency and consistency in statutory reporting by streamlining the application of common properties across multiple reports
  • Introduce a separate option to create or update reporting tasks, providing users with the flexibility to create or update reporting tasks as and when desired, rather than wait for the technical job to run

For more information please refer to :

  • Help Document: Trigger Mass Action
  • Define Statutory Reports
  • Help Document: Electronic Submission of Reports
  • Help Document: Mass Action
  • Help Document: Schedule Mass Action
  • Help Document: Update Reporting Tasks
  • Run Statutory Reports

Malaysia e-invoicing: exchange of electronic invoices through the Peppol network

Fig #3: Malaysia e-invoicing: exchange of electronic invoices through the Peppol network Malaysia e-invoicing regulation:

  • When you sell goods or services to a customer, you should create and submit an electronic invoice to the Inland Revenue Board of Malaysia (IRBM) first for clearance. Once the IRBM clears the electronic invoice, you can then send it to the customer.
  • Once the electronic invoice is cleared, you can then send it to your business partner over the Peppol network with SAP Document and Reporting Compliance, cloud edition.
  • As of May 28, 2025, official accreditation of SAP as a service provider and Peppol-ready solution provider by the Malaysia Digital Economy Corporation (MDEC).

Exchanging electronic documents (invoices, credit notes, debit notes) through the Peppol network is enabled.

More details: Sending Electronic Invoices to Customers Using Peppol

India Goods and services tax (GST) reporting - GSTR-1, GSTR-2A and GSTR-3B

Fig #4: India Goods and services tax (GST) reporting - GSTR-1, GSTR-2A and GSTR-3B

  • Monthly outward supplies return (GSTR-1):
    • Automated retrieval of auto-populated GSTR-1 from the goods and service tax network (GSTN) (in a draft return) and comparison against business transactions in the sales register in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
    • Review and finalization of the draft return, including the digital signature and filing
  • Inward purchase invoices and reconciliation:
    • Automatically retrieve GSTR-2A invoices from the GSTN portal and reconcile them against business transactions in the purchase register in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition
  • Monthly consolidated tax return (GSTR-3B):
    • Automated retrieval of data from GSTN (manual input of 2B data), review, and manual adjustment with traceability and filing

More details: India GSTR reports

Accelerated electronic document corrections with GenAI

Fig #5: Accelerated electronic document corrections with GenAI

As countries rapidly adopt e-invoicing mandates, tax accountants face growing challenges in handling complex, technical errors from high-volume electronic document exchanges. Joule with SAP Document and Reporting Compliance enables tax accountants to quickly understand these errors via clear explanations in natural language, without digging into complex formats and technical descriptions. This results in faster processing, reduced penalties, and improved cash flow—saving both time and money.​

Value Proposition​

  • Easy to understand explanations to complex electronic document errors.​
  • Uncover error root causes faster with resolution recommendations.​
  • Boost productivity and drive better business results.​
  • Better user experience with native language support.​

Capabilities​

  • User can simply ask Joule for error explanation in natural language.​
  • Get easy to understand context aware explanations.​
  • Error explanation include root cause and recommended resolution steps​
  • User can explore details via relevant SAP Help Documentation links provided.​
  • User can leverage multi-language capabilities for better experience. ​

For more information, see: Help Document: Electronic Document Error Handling with SAP Joule

SAP International Trade Management

Cloud BAdIs for Intrastat (BDT)

Fig #6: Cloud BAdIs for Intrastat (BDT)

Three cloud BAdIs are provided to select additional documents and change detail data. 

  • INTRASTAT_GET_BILLING_DOCS: to select additional billing documents not selected by standard selection report
  • INTRASTAT_GET_PURCHASE_DOCS: to select additional purchase documents not selected by standard selection report
  • INTRASTAT_CHANGE_DATA: to change data in documents selected by selection reports (which are selected via both standard and BAdIs)

For more information, please check New BAdI for Intrastat: Get Additional Purchasing Documents

Localization option for Intrastat (BDT) Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Cyprus, Malta

Fig #7: Localization option for Intrastat (BDT) Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Cyprus, Malta

Customers that want to implement Intrastat for non-standard countries, must use the SAP Central Business Configuration tool to access the new configuration items.

Configuration item 1: Basic data for Intrastat

Configuration item 2: Default values for Intrastat

Configuration item 3: Data selection for Intrastat

For more information, please see New Configuration Items for Intrastat Non-Standard Countries

New compliance status for purchase orders

Fig #8: New compliance status for purchase orders

With this feature, a Trade Compliance specialist can check on dedicated international trade compliance statuses for embargo, legal control, and screening in purchase orders.

Value Proposition

  • Gain transparency on dedicated statuses of international trade compliance checks in purchase orders
  • Help ensure frictionless international trade processes

Capabilities 

  • Dedicated international trade compliance statuses for embargo, legal control, and screening in purchase orders
  • New status fields to be available on purchase order header and item level in the purchase order advanced app
  • New status fields substitute the compliance status by the on-hold status in the purchase order

For more information, see Dedicated Trade Compliance Statuses in Purchase Orders​ and Product Compliance in Purchase Orders

Trade classification proposals for custom tariff numbers and commodity codes

 

Video #4: Trade classification proposals for custom tariff numbers and commodity codes

Increase productivity and leverage already existing trade product classifications for your decisions with AI-assisted trade classification proposals with fuzzy search

  • Step 1: Enable generation classification proposals for each numbering scheme
  • Step 2: Schedule jobs for classification proposals
  • Step 3: Optimize generated trade classification proposals (optional)

For more information, see:  Product Classification Proposal

Audit trail for Watch List Screening

 

Video #5: Audit trail for Watch List Screening

With this app you can display an audit trail for your screening requests. The app shows an overview of all screening requests. You can navigate to single screening requests for more information.

Value Proposition

  • Support audits by providing data

Capabilities 

  • The app shows an overview of all screening requests. You can navigate to single screening requests for more information.

For more information, see: Display Audit Trail

Thanks for taking the time to read this blog.

More Information

If you are interested in the latest and greatest blog posts on GRC Trade and Tax , please have a look at the collection blog.

Check out our community page to ask your questions and engage with the experts.

Follow the PSCC_Enablement tag to stay up to date with our latest blog posts. Follow us on @SAP

Watch the Replays of Our SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 Early Release Series!

From July 21 to July 25, we hosted a series of 21 compelling live sessions to highlight the exciting innovations shipped with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508 release. Missed the live sessions? We've got you covered! Take advantage of the entire series or pick and choose the sessions most relevant to you. You will find a 58-minute-long recording and a presentation for Finance as well as 20 other topics of interest. Don't miss this chance and watch them on demand  – anywhere, anytime.

Find All of Our Assets
